headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Fourth Quarter 2014 Financial Teleconference. My name is Sheila, and I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to M
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Fourth Quarter 2014 Financial Teleconference. My name is Sheila, and I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Scott Cunningham, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Cunningham, you may begin your conference.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sheila, and good afternoon, everyone. Our principal speakers will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here with us are other members of the management te
componenttext:
Thanks, Sheila, and good afternoon, everyone. Our principal speakers will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here with us are other members of the management team. The presentation that accompanies Jim's comments, the earnings press release and our Form 10-K are available on our website at www.edisoninvestor.com. After the call, we will be posting Ted's and Jim's prepared remarks. Tomorrow afternoon, we will distribute our regular business update presentation for use in upcoming investor meetings.
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about the financial outlook for Edison International and its subsidiaries. Actual results could differ materially from current expectations. Important factors that could cause different results are set forth in our SEC filings. Please read these carefully. The presentation includes certain outlook assumptions as well as reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to the nearest GAAP measure.
During Q&A, please limit yourself to 1 question and 1 follow-up. I'll now turn the call over to Ted Craver.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. We closed a good 2014 on a strong note. We delivered excellent financial performance. We resolved 2 major uncertainties, Edison Mission Energy and San Onofre. We meaningfully increased the dividend. We conti
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. We closed a good 2014 on a strong note. We delivered excellent financial performance. We resolved 2 major uncertainties, Edison Mission Energy and San Onofre. We meaningfully increased the dividend. We continue to fulfill the long-term growth opportunities at Southern California Edison through our focused investment strategy that supports California's environmental and growth objectives. And we continue to selectively pursue growth opportunities that allow us to serve additional customers outside of the CE service territory. Most gratifying to me is that we delivered on what we told investors we would do. I am proud of this leadership team and the outstanding work of our employees. That said, we fully recognize that 2014 is over and we are in the new year. We need to build on the performance of 2014 and continue to build value. With the strong fourth quarter, full year 2014 core earnings were $4.59 per share, an increase of 21% over the previous year. This result was well above our updated guidance from last fall. Jim Scilacci will cover more of the details in his comments. 
The settlements reached on the EME bankruptcy and the SONGS Order Instituting Investigation positioned us to move forward decisively in a time of tremendous change in our industry. The unanimous approval by the California Public Utilities Commission on the SONG settlement agreement last November demonstrated that it is possible to resolve complex and important regulatory matters through settlement. The settlement was the product of tough negotiations among the initial settling parties. The Utility Reform Network or TURN, the office of ratepayer advocate and the 2 utilities, and later other intervenor signed on to the settlement. The settlement has been widely supported as fair and balanced. SCE is now proceeding with implementation of the approved agreement. We are also deeply engaged in the planning and early stages of decommissioning the plant. SCE will continue to work aggressively to maximize potential financial recoveries from insurers and from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries. I'm hopeful SCE will be able to resolve the insurance claims this year. Under the provisions of the settlement agreement, virtually all insurance proceeds, if any, will go to customers. The arbitration process with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries must follow International Chamber of Commerce rules, which means that there'll be a slower process. I don't expect any decision until 2016. The MHI arbitration proceeding is confidential so we won't be able to say much. However, we continue to assert the claims we first presented to the International Chamber of Commerce in 2013. 
Our nearly 18% dividend increase in early December underscores our optimism about the future and our commitment to bringing our dividend payout closer to that of the industry. We expect to extend our record of 11 years of annual dividend increases while stepping up the pace of dividend growth to exceed that earnings. This will allow us to return to our target payout ratio of 45% to 55% of earnings in steps over time. 
Let me now provide some longer-term thoughts. On January 5, in his State of the State speech, Governor Brown outlined his broad goals for the next stage in addressing climate change. By 2030, he wants to derive 50% of the state's electricity from renewable sources, reduce petroleum in cars and trucks by 50% and double the efficiency of existing buildings. In his speech he said, "All of this is a very tall order. It means that we continue to transform our grid, our transportation system and even our communities." He continue saying, "I envision a wide range of initiatives, more distributed power, expanded rooftop solar, micro grids, and energy and balance market, battery storage, the full integration of information technology and electrical distribution and millions of electric and low carbon vehicles." The state's ambition and overall direction is clear. In broad strokes, we at Edison have been painting a similar picture of the future of the power system. Importantly, our growth strategy is aligned accordingly. Of course, the devils in the details. Some of the regulatory framework to implement this vision will require legislative action in and that process has already started in Sacramento. We will be actively engaged on the legislative front. One of our larger priorities will be achieving policy goals at the lowest cost to customers. We see the need to expand California's Renewable Portfolio Standard beyond the current regime of only recognizing large-scale wholesale contracted projects to recognize the benefits of distributed generation, energy efficiency and electric vehicle charging. The 3-year General Rate Case cycle provides a broad framework to incorporate other initiatives such as the Distribution Resource Plan required to be filed this summer. The CPUC recently issued its final guidance on the distribution plan elements. We anticipate that our plan will create something of a road map for the distribution system investments at Southern California Edison needed to realize the governor's vison. Some elements of the plan are already in process, including initiatives on energy storage, residential rate design and electric vehicle charging. California's commitment to creating a low carbon economy does not necessarily conflict with SCE's core mission of delivering safe, reliable and affordable electricity. SCE's current General Rate Case will establish the revenue requirement and scope of work to achieve both. The record for the rate case was completed in late January. The GRC is now in the hands of administrative law judges to develop a proposed decision. We expect a decision sometime in 2015. So with that, I'll now turn the call over to Jim Scilacci.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ted. Good afternoon, everyone. My comments will cover fourth quarter and full year 2014 earnings, our updated capital spending in rate base forecast and cost of capital. As we have previously stated, we will not provide 2015 earnings guidance unti
componenttext:
Thanks, Ted. Good afternoon, everyone. My comments will cover fourth quarter and full year 2014 earnings, our updated capital spending in rate base forecast and cost of capital. As we have previously stated, we will not provide 2015 earnings guidance until SCE receives its 2015 General Rate Case decision. In this presentation, I will, however, discuss assumptions relevant to our 2015 earnings. 
Please turn to Page 2. In the fourth quarter of 2014, SCE earned $1.09 per share or $0.30 ahead of last year. This increase was driven by many of the same factors we have been seeing during 2014, including higher revenue of $0.28 partially offset by depreciation of $0.08, net tax benefits and other items of $0.04 and O&M savings of $0.05. There are 2 -- there also are 2 items of note that are included in the $0.28 of higher revenue and both of them were not included in our updated earnings guidance that we provided last October. First, we recorded $0.05 of additional revenue from resolution of an open item from our 2012 GRC decision. During 2014, SCE team and IRS private letter ruling regarding appropriate treatment of net operating loss carryforwards. The net effect of the ruling was to increase CPUC rate base in revenues. In November, we obtain a CPUC approval authorizing the additional revenues. Second, you may recall that during the third quarter call, we thought that the energy efficiency awards might be delayed until 2015. As things turned out we received our award in December and it amounted to $0.04 per share. In the fourth quarter, the net SONGS impact on core earnings was a positive $0.02 per share compared to last year. Our fourth quarter results include recognition of revenue for the rate of return on the SONGS regulatory assets. We also had the $0.05 benefit some lower O&M cost, the largest item was lower severance expense. Taxes and other items were a net benefit of $0.04 per share led by $0.07 in higher income tax benefits. Most of this relates to repair deductions that we've talked about previously. At the Edison International parent company level, results were a loss of $0.01 per share compared to income of $0.02 per share last year, which is mainly due to the income from Edison Capital and tax benefits. The loss of $0.01 this quarter includes higher income from Edison Capital and lower tax benefits. As we have indicated, Edison Capital's remaining low-income housing portfolio continues to wind down as units were sold. 
Turning to noncore items. SCE recorded a net $0.08 per share benefit during the fourth quarter from our revised estimate of the impact of the SONGS settlement. There are a number of items that make up the $0.08 including the return on SONGS regulatory asset from April 1 through September 30 of this year and accrual of contribution University of California for greenhouse gas research. At the parent, we also recorded $0.12 per share benefit in discontinued operations related to resolution of uncertain tax positions from settlement of our 2003 to 2006 federal income tax years and other tax impacts related to EME. As a reminder, EIX has net operating losses and tax credit carryforwards from EME that will be monetized in future years as part of our settlement with EME creditors. These tax benefits were approximately $1.1 billion at year-end. We also recorded $0.01 per share net benefit of the holding company related to allocation of income tax attributes to tax equity investors and projects developed by SoCore energy on what is called a hypothetical liquidation at book value or HLBD accounting method. Because HLBD accounting procedures produces income not related to project portfolio performance, we classify this as income as noncore. 
Please turn to Page 3. For the full year, core earnings were $4.59 per share versus $1 -- excuse me, $3.80 in 2013. For SCE, this improvement is mainly due to rate base growth. Year-end 2014 rate base was $23.3 billion, a $2.2 billion increase over the prior year. In addition, SCE recorded higher net tax benefits totaling $0.16 per share principally from repair deductions and resolution of uncertain tax positions. A number of other smaller items complete the picture. At the holding company, core losses were comparable at last -- excuse me, to last year at $0.09 per share. This remains lower than expected primarily due to higher income from Edison Capital. I know many of you are interested in tracking our earnings relative to our guidance so I'll cover that next. 
Please turn to Page 4. This slide shows a reconciliation of core earnings to guidance over the full year period. I will focus on the final 3 months of the year that took us from $4.30 midpoint guidance in October to actual core earnings of $4.59. As you can see, the increase is $0.29. First, there's $0.10 per share of income tax benefits from additional repair and cost of removal deductions recorded in the fourth quarter. Next are the 2 items I mentioned earlier, the $0.05 per share benefit from the revised determination of rate base and $0.04 of energy efficiency awards. The balance relates to cost savings and a number of small items at $0.05 per share. Holding company core results were $0.04 per share better than expected primarily due to Edison Capital's affordable housing project revenues. 
Please turn to Page 5. SCE's capital spending forecast changed slightly from our prior forecast due to timing of transmission capital expenditures. Actual 2014 capital spending totaled $4 billion, $100 million below our forecast. Our outlook for 2015 spending is down $100 million and up $200 million in 2016. Please note we continue to use the 12% variability between the range and request capital's expenditure forecast. 
Please turn to Page 6. Our rate base forecast remains consistent with the 7% to 9% compound annual growth rates. Based on a number of changes, we revised downward our rate base forecast by a net $300 million by 2017. As the slide shows, this reflects an average reduction of $400 million from bonus depreciation and average reduction of $100 million for timing of transmission spending and a positive $200 million adjustment upward to update deferred taxes related to our smart connect project. Please note that the capital spending and rate base forecast do not include electric vehicle charging, energy storage or distribution resource plan expenditures. The lion's share of this spending, future spending will likely occur beyond the current forecast period. 
Please turn to Page 7. This page updates the interest rate trends for the CPUC cost of capital trigger mechanism. Recently, the CPUC approved a 1-year extension of our cost of capital mechanism. We must now file our 2017 cost of capital application in April 2016. The trigger mechanism will remain in effect from 2016. However, based on the movement of the Moody's BWA bond in the -- it seems unlikely that the current return on common equity of 10.45% would change for 2016. Our FERC filed rate settlement remains in place through the end of 2017. Under the settlement, the return on common equity can be reopened after June 30 of this year. 
Next, I'd like to touch on some financial considerations related to 2015 earnings given the absence of guidance. Please turn to Page 8. On this page, we have included some important factors to consider in our earnings estimates until we can provide formal guidance. The capital spending and rate base forecast are taken from Pages 4 and 5 of this presentation. Both CPUC and FERC return on common equity remain unchanged at 10.45%. We have some carryover items on energy efficiency awards from prior years. The potential earnings opportunity for 2015 is up to $0.05 rather than the more typical $0.03 for a single year. Please keep in mind that some of the carryover items will likely be contested by other parties, and there's no assurance that energy efficiency earnings will be approved. Another positive item is the completion in January of the SONGS regulatory asset financing. The approved settlement led SCE finance this asset with 100% debt. The settlement also requires that we share with our customers the cost savings of these financing if the rate is below the 2.62% return on the regulatory asset. SCE completed this financing with a weighted average cost of debt of 2.2%. The blended average rate increases over time due to debt amortization. After the cost sharing with customers, there's a very modest earnings benefit. However, the financing has the added benefit of ultimately freeing up approximately $400 million of common equity. As we recover the regulatory asset, this amount will decline over time. At year-end 2014, SCE's 13-month weighted average equity ratio for regulatory purposes was 48.4%. The SONGS regulatory asset totaled $1.288 billion at year-end 2014. Of this amount, $919 million earns the 2.62% return, $345 million earns a commercial paper rate and the balance earns no return. For 2015 and beyond, we believe that the return on SONGS regulatory asset will roughly match the financing cost. I will also remind you that our quarterly earnings results will not reflect the revenues requested in the 2015 GRC and, accordingly, won't have the typical profile during the year. Until we receive final GRC decision, we plan to record revenues based on the 2014 authorized revenue requirement. 
Please turn to Page 9. The next slide highlights the details of our dividend policy that Ted has already touched on. I'd like to reinforce our view that EIX has one of the better opportunities on large large-cap activities with rate base, earnings and dividend growth. 
Please turn to Page 10. This last slide captures our strategic framework. Ted has touched on many of the major points already. To summarize, we are very focused on delivering on our organic growth opportunity. We have a good growth visibility from our we're spending and the prospect for continued growth from a number of initiatives. However, as we have previously said, we will continue to work to optimize our cost structure and improve our operational efficiency. Thanks. I will now turn the call over to the operator for questions.

componenttextpreview: It's Julien here. So I wanted to ask kind of a bigger picture question here, as we think about this road map that you're getting ready to file. And I hear you in the broader elements here, you've got storage, you've got efficiency, you've got renewables i
componenttext: It's Julien here. So I wanted to ask kind of a bigger picture question here, as we think about this road map that you're getting ready to file. And I hear you in the broader elements here, you've got storage, you've got efficiency, you've got renewables in the background. What's going to be different versus the individual docket CR that we have filed? I mean, how does that bring together how does this from your perspective changed the capital spending plan and perhaps the different time period but just could you to elaborate a little bit?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll start. This is Jim Scilacci and I'll turn it over to Pedro for some additional comments. So the filing that's coming up in the second quarter, first part of the third quarter, we have a series of questions that PUC asks us to address. A lot of
componenttext: Okay, I'll start. This is Jim Scilacci and I'll turn it over to Pedro for some additional comments. So the filing that's coming up in the second quarter, first part of the third quarter, we have a series of questions that PUC asks us to address. A lot of them is really what's happening in the system and how we plan to address it to encourage and incorporate more distributed energy resources in distribution system. That is at least the initial filing is not an investment filing. It's really a description of what needs to be done and from our view. Others will have, I'm sure, different views. We will subsequently follow that up with probably some type of application or alternatively will include in our 2018 in general rate case request the actual expenditures associated with this new plan. And from overall perspective stepping back and thinking about our capital expenditures, we've said that capital expenditures on average have been running about $4 billion a year. And we don't want to suggest that these new programs either we'll take it up or drop it down. We think that generally going forward, capital expenditures will stay in that same zone even with these new initiatives. So I'll pause there and turn it over to Pedro for additional elaboration, if you want to add anything.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, I think you covered it very well. I think the July 1 filing fairly set of questions has posted daily go to the nuts and bolts of how build the grid need to evolve in order to accommodate the deployment distributed energy resources and look at the gri
componenttext: Jim, I think you covered it very well. I think the July 1 filing fairly set of questions has posted daily go to the nuts and bolts of how build the grid need to evolve in order to accommodate the deployment distributed energy resources and look at the grids capacity to integrate them, look at things like the value, various points across the grid. So the pace of this mechanical but broader piece around how this grid continue to evolve, raise questions and drive some insights on technologies and what's the evolution of that grid over time. And then as Jim said, we haven't determined this yet but we have the option of either including investment opportunities that we see in our future rate case cycles. Potentially there might be an opportunity to the separate filing. We saw a very pressing near-term need but that's we have underway right now in determining what those next steps are in and really developing the filing for July 1.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015

I mean, the Plus Size/other, is there anyway to beat that in 2015 without providing guidance here?

componenttext: I think that's what we are strongly suggesting when you look towards because your visibility on rate base and rate base growth and return on common equity, obviously, is not changing. So I think that's the best and safest way to do it for now.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to do just going back to the point Jim, why aren't there -- what you're suggesting is that the SONGS will reap 0 earnings per share to the bottom line?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I should've mentioned that. Steve asked that question. Thanks for picking it up. What I said in my prepared remarks were we believe that the return on the regulatory asset, that portion that's earning 2.62% and the financing that we put in place, the
componenttext: Yes, I should've mentioned that. Steve asked that question. Thanks for picking it up. What I said in my prepared remarks were we believe that the return on the regulatory asset, that portion that's earning 2.62% and the financing that we put in place, they tend to offset one another. So therefore, there won't be any earnings going to the bottom line for going forward. The other piece we talked about, there's a significant amount of nuclear fuel, which we're already financing with 100% debt at commercial paper rates so that seems to be match funded. So net-net-net, I don't see any change from that going forward that we should expect any earnings from San Onofre besides the cost. Scott, want to add anything?

I guess, just separately away from the utility as you think about your renewable strategy broadly, again outside of the utility, if you see the business continued to evolve, any high-level thoughts we should be thinking about? As I know you've talked about in the past about looking at how the business going to change. Obviously, there's a lot of changes on utility side but just curious outside of that, anything lately in terms of strategic thinking on renewables beyond the utility?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take a crack. This is Ted. Very broadly speaking as I kind of indicated in my opening comments, we see the potential in competitive businesses to serve customers outside of 50,000 square mile territory of Southern California Edison. Most of the word
componenttext: I'll take a crack. This is Ted. Very broadly speaking as I kind of indicated in my opening comments, we see the potential in competitive businesses to serve customers outside of 50,000 square mile territory of Southern California Edison. Most of the word that we've done up to this point has been focused more on commercial and industrial customers outside of the territory. Second to that, I would say our various potential electrification initiatives, so this would be projects that with further electrification we think that actually fits in to a lot of effort across the country but particularly here in California, the move towards a little carbon economy moving towards higher levels of electrification and say the transportation sector, goods movement, water, some of the other areas, all of that helps move the economy towards a lower carbon footprint. So those are kind of the second bucket of areas that we continue to look at. Final point I'll make is we tried to be fairly high level about the things that we're looking at on that side. I think you know us well enough by now we don't kind of come up with a lot of fanfare upfront. We'd rather see what we can deliver and then talk about that. So at this point, mostly effort it is on the distributed generation activities around SoCore and how that fits into our kind of broader strategy on the commercial and industrial customer side.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: You have mentioned couple of occasions the governor's vision for the upgrading of the great and also the need to continue to replace component and improve the reliability of your existing grid. Looking forward to your CapEx program in a longer time frame,
componenttext: You have mentioned couple of occasions the governor's vision for the upgrading of the great and also the need to continue to replace component and improve the reliability of your existing grid. Looking forward to your CapEx program in a longer time frame, would you be surprised to see the more or less $4.5 billion rate of CapEx that your forecasting for '15, '16, '17 to continue into the next PRC? Or would you be expecting factors to come into play that would move that $4.5 billion materially up or materially down?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. I think what we're attempting to say and I struggled with it in an earlier question, my response was I think the $4 billion is probably in the right zone, and we'll just have to see how things unfold. If you go through the piece parts, distri
componenttext: This is Jim. I think what we're attempting to say and I struggled with it in an earlier question, my response was I think the $4 billion is probably in the right zone, and we'll just have to see how things unfold. If you go through the piece parts, distribution has been stepping up in the total level of expenditures over the last several GRCs, and we are still working to get our placement rates to levels that we think we need to be at to maintain reliability of the electric system. So you could see distribution step up some of from where we are today. Transmission is more -- it's related to some of these large projects that we have flowing through and we have very modest transmission spending in years past and that stepped up as a result of all the renewable interconnections that we were doing. Generation is typically done a very small part of our overall equation. It was really just replacement capital expenditures mainly at our nuclear plants and it's dropped down to maybe about $100 million a year. So going forward, we'll have to see as we lay out the distribution resources plan, how significant and how fast the commission would want to move to make some of these improvements. We put out numbers on the electric vehicle charging. It's a little over -- it's approximately $350 million over a multi-year period of time. There's some storage expenditures. So I think it's best and safest to assume that $4 billion is probably the appropriate level until we can get more information in the public domain.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ted. Let me just throw in one other piece. I think the big consideration here is how fast you want to move towards modernizing the gride, converting it from largely electromechanical system to a much more digitized system, capable of two-way flows
componenttext: This is Ted. Let me just throw in one other piece. I think the big consideration here is how fast you want to move towards modernizing the gride, converting it from largely electromechanical system to a much more digitized system, capable of two-way flows electricity so on and so forth your of most of you heard us talk about before. If you envision doing that over 3- to 5-year period, then I think you probably be looking at higher numbers. If you envision doing that over 5- to 7-year period, it temps to -- If you envision doing over 10-year period, more modest yet. So I think a big component of trying to sort this through is the pace with which these investments get made not just the absolute number.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question, Ted, perhaps for you I wanted to delve a little more into your thinking on the dividend and when you talk about get into your targeted payout ratio or of the time, is the vision to --  I mean, the range of that you'll get to the middle of tha
componenttext: My question, Ted, perhaps for you I wanted to delve a little more into your thinking on the dividend and when you talk about get into your targeted payout ratio or of the time, is the vision to --  I mean, the range of that you'll get to the middle of that range -- the reason I bring it up is, when we run the math on the rate base map as Jim alluded to for the core earnings power of the it's going to be significantly lower than what you reported in '14 with all the tax benefits and cost savings, et cetera, that get with GRC. Arguably, you that you're pretty much most of the lower end of that range along those lines. And so I'm just curious, when you talk about still stepping up, what is it that you're envisioning for this dividend?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you put your finger in a really good point, we think we tended to think of it more in terms of what I would call to sustainable or durable earnings come it's always hard to predict. Certainly, 2014 was a good piece of it. It's always hard to predict
componenttext: When you put your finger in a really good point, we think we tended to think of it more in terms of what I would call to sustainable or durable earnings come it's always hard to predict. Certainly, 2014 was a good piece of it. It's always hard to predict just how much they're going to have in the way of some of these other earnings points. And, of course, I guess, it's possible you could have years where you end up having some of the more unusual items that work against you. But fundamentally, we kind of look at it as the core earnings power of the utility and the dividend is tied to SCEs earnings, really is the rate base model. So that's the way we tend to look at it. All of that said, we see continued significant growth in rate base and therefore, we see good growth in earnings. And in order to move the payout ratio up, we expect the growth rate in dividend increases to be higher than the growth rate in earnings. Otherwise, we won't make any progress on moving the payout ratio up.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. But just to clarify, I mean, the goal is not to necessarily get to the lower end, he we are there, the goal is to be somewhere in the middle of that range that you've given us.
componenttext: Understood. But just to clarify, I mean, the goal is not to necessarily get to the lower end, he we are there, the goal is to be somewhere in the middle of that range that you've given us.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Of course, I want take the bait to pinpoint where it will be inside the 45% to 55% payout ratio. But that's the target that we've had. And I think we look at all of the factors including what do we see the forward run rate in rate base growth because that
componenttext: Of course, I want take the bait to pinpoint where it will be inside the 45% to 55% payout ratio. But that's the target that we've had. And I think we look at all of the factors including what do we see the forward run rate in rate base growth because that's really what real drive earnings. And as I've said, we see good solid growth in rate base, therefore earnings, therefore dividends.

componenttext: It's a good question on breaking out the separate segment. We have it's too small now to justify doing that. So without Edison Capital, in any other tax benefits we would think in the normal course would be hitting about a little over $0.01 a month so you can do the math there and it's consistent with what we've said in the past.

But we're hoping in the commission renders final decision in the 2015 era proceeding, which is before them now, we should be fully collected in our under collection by year-end. And a part of piece parts coming to help that are the rate increase and the SONG settlement allows us to transfer some of the over collections to that under collection, and another critical piece is our decommissioning position because we have dollars that were spent for decommissioning that once we get approval, to get access to the decommissioning trust, we'll transfer those dollars over the era under collection. And hopefully, by year-end we'll be in good shape and obviously, the thing that's going to change up or down is what happens with gas prices. And based on the forecast we used for '15, I know for a fact that we're probably under running the actual expenditures because we used a higher forecast than gas prices are right now.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question, Michael. We have outstanding of $400 million note that comes due, I think, '17, if I'm not mistaken and we're considering what to do with that now. We added additional commercial paper borrowings and obviously, note payables to the EME cred
componenttext: Good question, Michael. We have outstanding of $400 million note that comes due, I think, '17, if I'm not mistaken and we're considering what to do with that now. We added additional commercial paper borrowings and obviously, note payables to the EME creditors, the total obligation was $600 million. We paid $200 million. We've got 2 more payments of $200 million in September this year and September of next year for $400 million and the whole source of repayment for majority of the borrowings we have outstanding to the really will be from the monetization of the EME tax benefits. I said in my script we've got $1.1 billion of NOLs and tax credit carry forwards. And if we don't get an extension of bonus depreciation in '15, likely SCE will be fully taxable asset as it run off its NOLs and will be then taking taxes to the federal government. Bonus doesn't apply to state government State of California so we're going to -- we're obviously, paying taxes for the state and then will start rapidly amortizing the EME benefits. One of the wildcards year and will have the consider and Ted mention in his comments, if we do get resolution of the SONGS litigation with MHI, we would look to take abandonment loss in a year that's result. We have to file a private letter ruling and we'll take a write-off and so that could affect, which will timing of a amortization tax benefits. But I think it's going to take out to '17, possibly in early '18 and fully amortized of the $1.1 billion of EME tax benefits.

componenttext: So the full case is before the commission. The update, hearings occurred in January, and so it's off to the ALJ's draft the proposed decision. Included in the case were some O&M savings that were identified as we are preparing the case and we are proposing that we would share 50% of those potential savings. And beyond that, I can't comment. I don't know what the commission is going to do, what the is propose and we just have to see ultimately unfolds. But 1 point I just want to emphasize, we will continue to look for cost savings to try to improve our efficiencies.

componenttext: Just as have a follow-up question. Ted, maybe you could just give us a little bit of color of we see all the headlines on PGNE and issues and you made 1 potential ex parte filings. Just how much is this impacting the ability to function on the normal things that you have to get done of the commission, including the getting the GRC done? And also just how should we think about the risk of you potentially having additional ex parte filings?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of affecting the business, I would say it doesn't really have a significant affect on the business. This is a fairly area but I would say generally speaking ex parte rules particularly on matters like the San Onofre matter, the OII, that's r
componenttext: Yes. In terms of affecting the business, I would say it doesn't really have a significant affect on the business. This is a fairly area but I would say generally speaking ex parte rules particularly on matters like the San Onofre matter, the OII, that's really designed to provide equal access to all parties to the proceeding with equal time. So it's I think one of the misconceptions something like SONGS OII that you're precluded from having conversations. You're not. It's just rules are designed to make sure that if we have conversations with decision-makers that those are noticed, that those -- that we included there how much time we spend with which decision-maker so that all the other parties have equal access, equal amount of time. That's the whole concept behind it. So I don't see any of this as hurting the ability to do business. It's complicated and cumbersome and sometimes kind of difficult on the interpretation of some of the specific provisions. But fundamentally, when it's -- when we have proceedings before the commission, we follow the rules. We go about doing the business the way it's really set up to do. There's plenty of opportunity in all of those proceedings for all parties to be heard. That's the kind of the point of having these things before the commission. So I don't see any big element there. Now I've got so warmed up on that part of the question I forgot the second part of your question.

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015

componenttext: Michael, it's Jim. Let me introduce Adam Umanoff. He is our EIX General Counsel. He joined us in January. We're happy to have him. So, Adam, could you pick up that question?

headline: Edison International, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim, happy to do so. Good afternoon. You asked about the application for rehearing and a federal lawsuit. I'm taking one at a time. An application for rehearing was filed by the coalition to decommission San Onofre and that was filed in the end of l
componenttext: Sure, Jim, happy to do so. Good afternoon. You asked about the application for rehearing and a federal lawsuit. I'm taking one at a time. An application for rehearing was filed by the coalition to decommission San Onofre and that was filed in the end of last year, mid-December 2014. They're basically, asking for California Public Utility Commission to reconsider their decision approving the SONGS settlement. And the basis for their request is a bunch of alleged procedural irregularities in the proceeding undertaken by the CPUC. It's our review that there really is no legitimate basis for the CPUC to overturn the settlement based upon the theories that they answered by the coalition to decommission San Onofre. But, of course, that's for the CPUC to decide. All the parties to the SONGS settlement have filed a joint response in early January rejecting the request for rehearing. The CPUC did not operate under a firm deadline to respond but they normally respond within 3 to 5 months, so we should expect to hear from the CPUC by the middle of March to the middle of May. Separately, another plaintiff, Citizen Oversight, who happens to be represented by the same lawyer who represents the coalition for the commission San Onofre filed a federal court action down in San Diego. And basically, raised some constitutional theories that the SONGS atonement was an impermissible taking off rate payer property. That suit was filed in November of 2014. Both we and the CPUC filed motions to dismiss at the end of January, to be some further paperwork back and forth as that reply and we again reply in February and March. And if all goes well we expect a decision from the federal court in April of 2015, so in a couple of months.
