headline: Edison International, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pedro again. And I'll keep this at a pretty high level. One of the reasons that we have the range there is that, especially, as we start getting out into that 2018 to 2020 time frame, a lot of the -- our view on the DRP is colored by our internal
componenttext: This is Pedro again. And I'll keep this at a pretty high level. One of the reasons that we have the range there is that, especially, as we start getting out into that 2018 to 2020 time frame, a lot of the -- our view on the DRP is colored by our internal forecasting of the pace of adoption of technologies. And how that pace of adoption varies across different parts of our system. For example, the capital spending forecast that we included in the DRP filing are really focused on urban areas. We are assuming that rural areas would not have as quick a pace of adoption that might happen in later years. We've taken a stab, at what circuits might have a faster level of adoption versus a slower level of adoption. So I think that ranging there really is coupled back to where do customers end up choosing to deploy these technologies? How quickly they do it? And what things do we need to do to ensure that our grid is ready to plug and play their choices. That's really the range as opposed to more a determinative decision on our part to invest here or there. Some of this is that we're really changing the mindset here to make sure that we are supporting having a grid that's robust and that can keep pace and be ready for customer choices, but we're taking a bit of a stab at this point as to what those customer choices will be.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Travis, you can see on Page 6 of the investor deck, the breakout of the spending, $0.5 billion of the loan is the grid reinforcement. As what Pedro alluded to, it's taking the lower voltage circuits and taking it to higher voltage levels to prepare for a
componenttext: Travis, you can see on Page 6 of the investor deck, the breakout of the spending, $0.5 billion of the loan is the grid reinforcement. As what Pedro alluded to, it's taking the lower voltage circuits and taking it to higher voltage levels to prepare for a more distributed generation. And not just pace, how fast you want to make those changes. And that's a choice that we'll have to make and the commission will have to make together.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other variable that we cited in the filing is, again, we are making forecast based on our current view and the market's current view of technologies available. For example, communication systems, we know we will need to broaden, expand the capabilitie
componenttext: One other variable that we cited in the filing is, again, we are making forecast based on our current view and the market's current view of technologies available. For example, communication systems, we know we will need to broaden, expand the capabilities of our field area network. We are building these capital numbers based on the view of what those technologies will cost today, but we all know that computing communications technologies are on a very fast development curve and so those -- the actual prices, the actual cost for those technologies can vary significantly as we head out a few years out.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I think I'd probably want to leave investors with the emphasis being on -- we've stated numerous times what our objective is. We've also stated numerous -- and that's to return to the 45% to 55% payout ratio for SCE earnings. And w
componenttext: That's a good question. I think I'd probably want to leave investors with the emphasis being on -- we've stated numerous times what our objective is. We've also stated numerous -- and that's to return to the 45% to 55% payout ratio for SCE earnings. And we've also stated that it will take -- it's not all going to happen in one shot. We've made a very large kind of move last year. We want to continue to make solid moves in order to get back to that payout ratio. So that's where I would want to put the emphasis. To say that we'll do that, come hell or high water, you never can say that. You have to take into consideration capital requirements, take into consideration all of these other proceedings but at least as we see it today, they all look like they're manageable within the context of continuing to make progress and deliver on our -- one of our core objectives of getting back to the payout ratio of 45% to 55%.

componenttext: This is Pedro again. I don't believe that the Cal ISO has published the cost estimates or revenue requirement for that project. The goal we have at this point, is a statement from the ISO that, in their view, the proposed cost for that Abengoa team were significantly less than those of the next competitor. I don't think the ISO has publicized who the next competitor was. So it's tough to speculate on what some of the key drivers would've been, but when you think around cost of transmission project, key elements would include everything from the upstream, design of the project, what kind of towers, what kind of conductors, to right-of-way as you suggested, to environmental impacts and mitigating those impacts depending on what route you choose to the cost of the actual construction labor you're using. So very difficult for us to speculate on what it would have been, but we, again, we know that the ISO said that the choice was based on the lower revenue requirement and also binding caps on capital costs and -- as well as the return on equity.

componenttext: It's a possibility. We've deferred it once already. This is the first time -- we've done it in the past. You can see it, you can see what's happening with it. So there's a strong desire on our part to continue to use it. If we can get an extension, that would be great. And it seems like it's coming right back to where we started 3 years ago, well, now 4, if we get further on here. So the mechanism has worked well given what we're trying to do.

componenttext: Let me answer that. It's Adam Umanoff. There is a hearing coming up in the middle of August directly related to x party governance issues at the CPUC. headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Third Quarter 2015 Financial Teleconference. My name is Brandon, I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Third Quarter 2015 Financial Teleconference. My name is Brandon, I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Scott Cunningham, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Cunningham, you may begin your conference.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brandon, and welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team. Material
componenttext:
Thanks, Brandon, and welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team. 
Material supporting today's call are available on www.edison.com. The key items are our Form 10-Q, Ted and Jim's prepared remarks and the presentation that accompanies Ted's comments -- Jim's comments. Tomorrow afternoon, we will distribute our regular business update presentation. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about the future outlook for Edison International and its subsidiaries. Actual results could differ materially from current expectations. Important factors that could cause different results are set forth in our SEC filings. Please read these carefully. 
The presentation includes certain outlook assumptions as well as reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to the nearest GAAP measure.  [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Ted.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported core earnings of $1.16 per share. While this is well below last year's third quarter core earnings of $1.52 per share, year-over-year third quarter earnings comparisons, as was the case wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported core earnings of $1.16 per share. While this is well below last year's third quarter core earnings of $1.52 per share, year-over-year third quarter earnings comparisons, as was the case with the first two quarters of the year, are not very useful. This is because of the way we have had to recognize revenue with the delay in SEC's 2015 general rate case and how we are accounting for the recently released proposed position.
We have said in the past that we would provide 2015 earnings guidance when we receive a final GRC decision. However, with the noise on our quarterly earnings numbers, we thought it a disservice to investors to have them guessing about 2015 earnings, therefore we decided it was best to provide 2015 guidance at this time today. 
So today, we introduced core earnings guidance for 2015 of $3.77 to $3.87 per share. This guidance has some key assumptions that Jim will review in his comments.
Of course, should the final GRC decision differ substantially from the proposed decision, we may have to revisit our guidance. We plan to return to our normal practice of providing annual earnings guidance for 2016 when we report full year 2015 results in late February.
One more comment on the General Rate Case. While we feel the GRC proposed decision is overall generally constructive, SCE identified several important issues in its October 8 comments to the CPUC. Jim will cover most of these, but I want to touch on one in particular. 
The proposed decision attempts to recover certain tax repair benefits that were reflected in earnings in 2012 to 2014 through a permanent reduction to rate base of $344 million. We consider this retroactive ratemaking and a potential violation of internal revenue service rules. We are hopeful that the CPUC will correct their legal error. If the commission were to adopt the proposed decision's retroactive treatment of repair deductions, then SCE would be forced to write-off some or all of the $380 million regulatory asset related to future recovery of taxes.
The final decision on SCEs General Rate Case is currently scheduled for the November 5 CPUC meeting. 
I assume most if not all of you are aware of the administrative law judge's proposed decision released yesterday on penalties related to SONGS ex parte communications. In short, the ALJ found in our PD that there were 8 communications that were late reported to the commission and found 2 rule 1.1 violations. The PD proposed a $16.74 million penalty on Southern California Edison. There are additional procedural steps yet to come on this issue, but we are thankful that this appears to be moving towards resolution.
This has been a painful episode including for Edison, and I feel obliged to make several comments on it. First, I want to set the record straight on some misconceptions that are constantly being repeated. Contrary to the many reports, SCE has not engaged "improper talks or communications with regulators" related to the SONGS' OII. The important distinction is that the judge found that we didn't report in a timely manner permissible communications with regulators. The communications themselves were not found to be improper or illegal under the ex-party roles as certain parties have repeatedly and wrongly asserted.
In our recent filing, we maintained that 7 of these 8 communications were either not required or outright not allowed to be reported under the ex parte roles. The difference of opinion is a direct result of ambiguity in California is overly complicated ex parte roles. 
The Ambiguous rules require the parties to do their best to interpret them and practice, which creates a risk. We believe the rules need to be clarified and simplified so that we do not find ourselves underwriting the risk of after-the-fact reviews. It is worth noting that even the ALJ concluded in her P.D. that the ex parte rules were are ambiguous and cited that as a mitigating factor in calculating the penalty. As I said in an earnings call a few quarters ago, we look forward to working with President Bicker to clarify the ex parte roles soon. 
Many of the matters we deal within our business involve tough judgment calls and contentious proceedings under ambiguous rules and conditions. We don't particularly like it, but it comes with the territory. We expect controversy. We also expect a great deal of ourselves and our employees because we provide such an essential service to society and we rely on the public trust.
That is why it is important to do the right thing. We expect nothing less of ourselves. We want to earn the trust of our customers, the public and the CPUC-based on our conduct. While we aren't perfect and there will be times when we fail to live up to our own expectations and those of others, we must, and we do, set high standards of conduct for ourselves.
We have an obligation to be transparent and open and we will redouble our efforts to conduct ourselves in this manner. We will also work hard to support President Vickers efforts to clarify and improve the current poorly-crafted ex parte name roles. Strong efforts on both fronts will go a long way to avoiding a repeat of this in the future.
On a brighter note, we were pleased to report last week the settlement reached with Nuclear Electric Insurance Limited, known as NIOL, on insurance claims related to the shutdown of the Center for Nuclear Generating Station. The settlement is for $400 million and covers all insurance claims by the 3 owners of SONGS related to the events leading to the shutdown. All necessary approvals have been received from the owners and NIOL.
This is another important step in implementing the SONGS' settlement approved unanimously by the CPUC last November. Consistent with the SONGS' settlement, insurance recoveries will first pay associated legal cost and then 95% will be allocated to customers and 5% to the owners.
SCE customers will receive its allocation as a credit to the purchase power balancing account known as ERRA. Assuming payment from NIOL received in the fourth quarter, then customer benefit should show up in their books as a reduction of purchased power cost in 2016.
The larger claim against Mitsubishi Heavy Industries for the failed design of the replacement steam generators continues to proceed under binding arbitration through the International Chamber of Commerce. We still expect a decision on that case by late 2016.
SCE's share of the NIOL recoveries and any MHI recoveries including recovery of legal cost will be treated as non-core. That is, they will not be included in our core earnings.
There's still much procedurally to be accomplished before the SONGS' OII in related matters can be completed. We are hopeful that this is all moving towards a conclusion this year or early next. We continue to believe that no new information has been presented to suggest that the SONGS' settlement was anything other than independently-negotiated,  -- warrants continued full support by the CPUC and its customers.
I'd like to turn to a couple of items that address some of our longer-term growth opportunities, starting with SCEs distribution resources plan or DRP.
Since the July 1 filing, we have seen tremendous interest amongst stakeholders and some encouraging early support from a number of parties on our conceptual long-term approach. Appropriately, there will be concerns about cost and the pace of implementation, of building a flexible twenty-first century grid as outlined in our DRP filings. We are awaiting a more definitive schedule for the balance of the preceding, which the CPUC indicates will be completed next spring. This should give SCE adequate time to incorporate DRP elements into its 2018 to 2020 General Rate Case, which we expect to file in the Fall of 2016. 
Moving on, the California Legislature provided its own form of support for Governor Brown's low carbon goals and the DRP with the passage of Senate Bill 350. The governor signed this bill into law earlier this month. Senate Bill 350 will move renewables targets to 50% of delivered energy from qualifying renewable resources by 2030. The current renewables target is 53% of delivered power by 2020. The new law provides some valuable implementation flexibility that will help us meet the goals at the lowest reasonable cost to our customers. It also provided legislative support for future utility investment and transportation electrification. This is one of the long-term growth opportunities that we see for Southern California Edison, just as we see similar opportunities around electrical -- electric vehicle charging infrastructure and energy storage as complements to SCEs wire-focused investment strategy.
One final comment. I continue to believe that we have an attractive multiyear dividend opportunity that complements a strong earnings growth outlook. The GRC-proposed decision, the DRP and SB 350 are all data points that underscore SCEs growth potential. This in turn reaffirms the dividend growth opportunity I discussed on recent earnings calls. We recognize that for a few years now, we have been below our targeted payout ratio of 45% to 55% of SCE's earnings. We remain committed to moving well into that target range in steps over time.
Hopefully, we will be well along the way to resolution on both the SONGS' OII and the GRC before the Board's usual December consideration of the dividend increase. Even if both are not fully resolved by then, I don't see it impacting our ability to continue to implement our dividend policy. 
That concludes my comments. Now Jim will provide his financial report.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ted. Good afternoon, everyone. I plan on covering third quarter and year-to-date results, SCEs 2015 General Rate Case proposed decision, capital spending and rate-based forecast, a few other financial topics and guidance. Please turn to Page 2-two
componenttext:
Thanks, Ted. Good afternoon, everyone. I plan on covering third quarter and year-to-date results, SCEs 2015 General Rate Case proposed decision, capital spending and rate-based forecast, a few other financial topics and guidance. Please turn to Page 2-two of the presentation. 
Let me first address revenue recognition for the first 6 months and then for the third quarter. For the first two months of the year -- for the first two quarters of the year, we recorded revenues largely based on 2014 authorized revenues, which included a revenue in deferral of $85 million or $0.16 per share related to incremental flow-through, tax repaired deductions. Our accounting was based on management judgment that these revenues refunded to customers. Having received the proposed decision, we had updated our estimates of probable refunds to customers as part of our third quarter reporting.  This in turn lowered third quarter revenues. 
The GRC-related revenue deduction was $0.42 per share. This is comprised of the 2 elements shown under key earnings drivers at the right of the slide.
As Ted noted, earnings comparisons will not be useful until we receive a final GRC decision and report full year 2015 earnings. Of course, if the final GRC decision is different than the proposed decision, then there could be other related adjustments. With that background, I'd like to walk through the key earnings drivers starting with SCE. 
There are 2 key earnings drivers of the $0.35 per share decline in SCEs earnings. First, as I mentioned before, we recorded revenue largely based on the GRC-proposed decision, including a catch-up adjustment. Second, there were favorable cost and tax benefits realized in 2014, which did not recur in 2015.
Looking at revenue, I've highlighted the $0.42 per share-related to the GRC-proposed decision. $0.20 of this revenue reduction is from the flow through tax repair benefits to customers with a related offset in the form of higher tax repair deductions. The remaining decrease in GRC revenues are $0.22 per share. Also we continue to see revenue increases from a growing FERC rate base and higher operating costs. This is a positive $0.02 per share.
Lastly, please note that the revenue variances is a net of SONGS' for comparability. The SONGS detail are footnoted below. 
Moving to O&M, SCE had $0.03 per share and higher cost this quarter versus the third quarter of last year. This includes $0.01 per share of additional severance at SCE. Depreciation is $0.02 per share higher primarily due to transmission and distribution investments. Net financing cost provided a $0.02 per share benefit, primarily due to higher earnings from AFUDC.
Turning to taxes. I've already covered the $0.20 per share for the 2015 repair deductions. Most of the remaining variants relates to $0.11 per share in earnings from incremental repair deductions recorded last year.
In all, SCEs third quarter core earnings are $1.19 per share, down $0.35 from last year.
For the holding company, costs are $0.01 per share higher than last year, largely from lower income from Edison capital. I'll come back to Edison Capital later in my remarks. 
Noncore earnings in the quarter of $0.13 per share largely relate to the EME bankruptcy, tax benefits and insurance recoveries.
Please turn to Page 3. We addEd this slide to simplify the explanation of third quarter core earnings. As you can see, the differences -- the difference on this slide versus the prior slide is that we netted out the impact of lower revenues and income tax benefits related to repair deductions in 2015. As indicated on this slide, the 2 key drivers are the lower revenues based on the GRC-proposed decision of $0.22; and the $0.11 of 2014 incremental repair deductions.
That gets us to $0.33 of the $0.35 reduction in third quarter core SCE earnings. Please turn to Page 4.
For year-to-date earnings, GRC related revenue is $0.58 per share lower, reflecting the $0.42 for the third quarter and the $0.16 for the first half of the year. Again, this is a mix of a lower tax repair revenues, $0.30 -- $0.36 per share, which is offset in taxes and the third quarter revenue adjustment of $0.22 per share.
Most of the cost items continue their trend. And for the year-to-date, we also have higher depreciation and O&M and lower financing costs from higher AFUDC earnings.
You We also see the significant impact in both years related to changes in uncertain tax positions and lower tax benefits in other areas. Last year, we also had the generator settlements and other items that are absent this year. All in, year-to-date SCE core earnings are $3.31 per share, down $0.27 from last year.
Page 5 has a similar waterfall chart of year-to-date core earnings. 
Please turn to Page 6. This slide compares the key revenue and rate base differences between the 2015 GRC-proposed decision and SCE's updated request. The revenue adjustments are recorded in the third quarter largely reflect the 3 quarters worth of proposed decisions authorized annual revenue.
Please turn to Page 7. This slide summarizes the most important issues identified in SCEs comments on the proposed decision. Ted has already talked about the tax repare deduction issue. Next is the customer deposit issue. Since the 2003 GRC, the CPUC has weakened customer deposits as a rate base offset. However, PG&E and Sanyo Gas Electric do not have this adjustment. The third item is a proposed reduction in the poll-loading program. The proposed decision did not approve approximately $100 million of capital, which has a 2015 rate base impact of $73 million, putting aside the rate base adjustment for repair deductions, the proposed decision would adopt 92% of our requested capital. This is higher than previous GRC's and of course, this percentage could change the final decision. 
I will note the 2 other key issues. The principal one is incentive compensation. The proposed decision recommended significant reductions and authorized revenues related to incentive compensation for the entire workforce, even though the jointly sponsored SCE and compensation study concluded, SCEs total compensation is an average 5% below market. We are strong believers in pay-for-performance compensation philosophy and incentive-based compensation for all employees, not just executives as a fundamental element of that philosophy. This reduction is larger than experience in prior cases. 
Lastly, there is a $10 million disallowance for a contract termination payment dating back to SCE's rooftop solar initiative. We believe the termination payment is reasonable and benefit the customer substantially. 
In accounting for the quarter, the revenue adjustment track the proposed decision except for 2 items: The tax item; and the solar program contract cancellation disallowance. I'll pick this up later when I discussed rate base forecast and earnings guidance.
Please turn to Page 8. Pages 8 and 9 update forecasted capital expenditures and rate base for the GRC-proposed decision and known FERC-related capital expenditure changes. SCE's experiencing licensing and permitting delays with 2 -- with a few of its transmission projects, notably the West Endeavors project. As a result, the timing of expenditures was moved out beyond 2017. Once SCE files its 2018 GRC application and we update our CapEx and rate-based forecast, these delayed expenditures will appear back in the forecast. The FERC adjustments are shown on the right side of the slide. The balance of the reduction is related to the GRC proposed decision, largely infrastructure replacement, inspection and maintenance and nonelectric facility capital projects.
Historically, we have shown what we call a request level of capital expenditures and rate base in a lower range level. As you can see on the chart, on Pages 8 and 9, we have replaced the word request with the word outlook. Where CPUC capital, we now forecast that we will spend all authorized dollars for 2015 through 2017. For FERC Capital, we have continued our practice of reducing outlook expenditures by 12% to arrive at the range level of expenditures.
Once we file our 2018 General Rate Case, we will revert back to using both request and range monikers. 
As a reminder, the CPUC capital expenditures do not include any distribution resources, plan expenditures. We have asked the commission to approve a memorandum account so we can track costs associated with the DRP spending. So if we were to spend all authorized CPUC amounts provided in the GRC-proposed decision, then we would need to have the DRP memorandum account in place in order to be allowed to see cost recovery in the next GRC.
Beyond 2017, we still believe the long-term capital spending will continue to run at least $4 billion annually. And spending could be higher depending upon CPUC approval and future rate cases.
Please turn to Page 9. Based on a revised capital spending forecast from the prior slide, we have updated our rate-based forecast. The updated rate base forecast yields compound annual growth rates of 8% from 2017 -- '15 through 2017. The prior forecasts was 7% to 9% annually. Consistent with our accounting for the proposed decision, we have not factored in the proposed $344 million reduction in rate base related to the disputed tax repair deduction issue in this forecast. If a final GRC decision about the rate base adjustment, then each of the year's rate base would decline by the adjustment amount.
Please turn to Page 10. As expected, the CPUC cost of capital mechanism did not trigger any change in allowed ROE for 2016. While the Spot, Moody's, PW utility Index rate moved quite a bit, the moving average dampened the full year impact. Starting October 1, we began the new measurement period starting with the moving average where the spot rate ended at September 30 at 5.45%. We are currently scheduled to file our next cost of capital application in April of 2016.
Please turn to Page 11. This page covers a handful of other financial topics. SCEs weighted average common equity component, for regulatory purposes, was 49.5% at September 30, increasing from 48.9% we reported in the second quarter. This excess equity gives us additional financial flexibility.
Next, you will recall that SCEs fuel and purchase power balance account, or ERA have been deeply under collected as recently as year-end 2014. With the previous rate increase, SONGS settlement refunds, lower natural gas costs and the balancing account has moved to an over collective position of $112 [ph] million as of September 30.
When SCE receives the new settlement proceeds, expect it in the fourth quarter, they will be credited to era.
Turning to the holding company. Last month, we renewed an EIX holding company shelf registration to provide us flexibility to access the capital markets as needed for liquidity and general purposes. EIX commercial paper outstanding was $738 million as of September 30, compared to a total EIX credit facility of $1.18 million [ph]. 
Also early this month, we reached an agreement to sell our remaining affordable housing portfolio at Edison Capital. Terms of the transaction have not yet disclosed pending final due diligence and negotiations. In any case, the amounts are not material and the transaction will be treated as non-core.
For the past few years, Edison Capital Earnings have helped offset capital cost. 
Please turn to Page 12. This page provides the detail of our 2015 earnings guidance that Ted discussed. We have followed the same approach we have used the last several years. We start with SCE rate base earnings. We used the 23.1 billion [ph] weighted average rate base outlook as shown on Page 10. Based on SCEs authorized capital structure and flat share count, that gets us to $3.56 [ph] per share of rate-based earnings. We then identified $0.41 per share of SCE items that take earnings higher. The principal item is the $0.31 per share revision to uncertain tax provisions recorded in the second quarter. We have also discussed AFUDC being a net positive factor for the year rather than just offsetting costs not recovered by the General Rate Case revenues. 
We continue to estimate $0.05 of energy efficiency earnings in the fourth quarter as previously disclosed. We have recorded severance cost of $0.03 year-to-date. The balance of all our items is a positive penny a share, including the ex parte proposed penalty. We have estimated full year holding company cost at $0.15, getting us to a midpoint of $3.82 per share.
To the right, we have included key guidance assumptions. We had excluded a shareholder portion of the NIOL settlement proceeds and related litigation cost. We consider these revenues non-core. Our guidance tracks our accounting for the GRC-proposed decision, so it excludes the $344 million rate base adjustment for repair deductions and the solar termination payment disallowance. 
That concludes my comments. I would turn the call over to the operator to moderate the Q&A.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understood. And then just a follow-up -- on just thinking about the tax positions you highlighted in 2015. There are a number of moving parts in terms of uncertain tax positions and lower tax benefits. On a going-forward basis in '16 [ph] and beyond
componenttext: Okay. Understood. And then just a follow-up -- on just thinking about the tax positions you highlighted in 2015. There are a number of moving parts in terms of uncertain tax positions and lower tax benefits. On a going-forward basis in '16 [ph] and beyond, without being specific numerically, how should we think about those kinds of moving parts? When do they start to settle down? And when will they become less materialist as we think about future years?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, and it really depends on how ultimately things turn out. I can tell you for repair deductions, that's been a challenging one for us to forecast accurately. And I wouldn't expect that, going forward, that you will see potential shar
componenttext: That's a good question, and it really depends on how ultimately things turn out. I can tell you for repair deductions, that's been a challenging one for us to forecast accurately. And I wouldn't expect that, going forward, that you will see potential shareholder benefits from repairs. But there could be other tax benefits we realized, so it really becomes to how accurate we are forecasting our cost versus what actually occurs. So there could be, there could be differences, both for or against us. And the other related piece is O&M benefits, that's the other companion we've been talking about this whole time, where I think in the proposed decision, it was clear that it left open the door that there could be incremental O&M savings that we could realize and we've said repeatedly that we will continue to look for benefits to reduce our cost of our customers.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then as you think about those moving parts, is that in terms of the magnitude of volatility? I know it's hard to have a crystal ball to think about that. But do you see the same degree of potential volatility in terms of movements in
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then as you think about those moving parts, is that in terms of the magnitude of volatility? I know it's hard to have a crystal ball to think about that. But do you see the same degree of potential volatility in terms of movements in these accounts? Or are there reasons why that volatility might be reduced in future years?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think my answer around that was because around repair deductions was was talking about specifically, the proposed decision, I think, effectively will probably capture those benefits. And there's also a balancing account that's been set up for our p
componenttext:
Yes, I think my answer around that was because around repair deductions was was talking about specifically, the proposed decision, I think, effectively will probably capture those benefits. And there's also a balancing account that's been set up for our pool loading program, where a lot of the repair deductions are arising from. That's why these repair benefits have increased so dramatically over the last 3 years. So with that balancing account, there's not an opportunity for earnings or losses associated with differences in forecast. 
A lot will be there. Sorry -- there's still more to be written here until we get a final decision.

componenttext: It's Julien here. So just following on the transmission reductions in the rate base. Can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of the issues and pushing up this CapEx Part 1? And perhaps Part 2, you talked about a $4 billion number, but is it fair to say that there might be some higher oscillations in that call it rounded $4 billion number in the '18 period now that you've pushed out the transition CapEx? Just trying to get a sense what's going on in terms of the pieces.

componenttext: Sure. I'll just point you to Page 8 in the investor deck, which has the capital expenditures. And it provides the detail of the amounts that are changing. In terms of the reasons, what my script followed up on was these are permitting and scheduling delays. And principally, the largest one is the West of Devers project. There's some other smaller ones, but West of Devers is a rather large project and we're just seeing it slip out in time. And I'll pause and look at Pedro and Maria, see if there's anything else to add. So that's what you've got. Now as far as the above $4 billion...

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I suppose just to clarify. You guys have historically talked about hitting a $4 billion CapEx phase consistently. Does this now mean that you have, call it a 2018 number that's not filming here that would be, call it, materially above that $4 billion figu
componenttext: I suppose just to clarify. You guys have historically talked about hitting a $4 billion CapEx phase consistently. Does this now mean that you have, call it a 2018 number that's not filming here that would be, call it, materially above that $4 billion figure to reflect, call it, a onetime true-up on the CapEx for transmission?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And this is going to be a difficult one because we don't have information in the public domain beyond '17. So I'm just going to touch a couple of items that we see that are changing, both up and down to be fair. So clearly, the DRP is a big element o
componenttext: Yes. And this is going to be a difficult one because we don't have information in the public domain beyond '17. So I'm just going to touch a couple of items that we see that are changing, both up and down to be fair. So clearly, the DRP is a big element of potential new expenditures. We've provided information of public domain. And you can see the substantial ramp-up of expenditures in '17 and as you go into '18. But those expenditures will be subject to review as part of our General Rate Case process. There are other things that are going up, that would include -- we have an opportunity through the storage program. We have an opportunity through electric vehicle charging program. And those are still working their way through -- and all 3 of those just emphasize are not included in the numbers we're not seeing here today. So there's potential upside depending upon how those proceedings progress. On the downside, there is the transmission issue is there still going to be a lot to see where that goes. As you finish some of these larger projects, we've ramped up in transmission area then we ramped back down as we finished and we'll get to a steady state of capital expenditures. And we'll just have to see how load growth goes. That could be up or down depending upon health of the service territory and the penetration of distributed generation resources. So I leave it there. There's ups and downs. There's probably more of a bias that we see to the upside because of some of these larger projects.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you look at our forecasts, they take the $180 million of customer deposits and reduce our rate base by that amount. And the bono contentions is there's not similarity of treatment among the 3 utilities. We seem to be treated differently as a result o
componenttext: When you look at our forecasts, they take the $180 million of customer deposits and reduce our rate base by that amount. And the bono contentions is there's not similarity of treatment among the 3 utilities. We seem to be treated differently as a result of whatever reason. And we've had this -- we keep raising this issue in the last several GRCs, and there is inconsistent treatment. We think that's unfair.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, on the first point, I agree with everything you severe in the second bullet, which seems like a rate-making violation of normalization regulations etc. But presumably, the ALJ who has a lot of -- and I don't -- has a different view. Can
componenttext: Okay. And finally, on the first point, I agree with everything you severe in the second bullet, which seems like a rate-making violation of normalization regulations etc. But presumably, the ALJ who has a lot of -- and I don't -- has a different view. Can you characterize the different perspectives around this point?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It would be hard to characterize it completely. There's a number of arguments. But I think the simple argument that was made is that they set rates prospectively, so therefore how could it be retroactive ratemaking? We just fundamentally disagree on
componenttext: Yes. It would be hard to characterize it completely. There's a number of arguments. But I think the simple argument that was made is that they set rates prospectively, so therefore how could it be retroactive ratemaking? We just fundamentally disagree on that point. And so that's something we'll have to figure out, hopefully, in the final decision, they'll address this issue. But we'll have to see.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the course of action here, I know Pedro talked about in the oral arguments and in our comments in the proposed decision, that retroactive ratemaking and you have a legal lead recourse. And there's a potential, as Ted said in his script of an IRS issue,
componenttext: In the course of action here, I know Pedro talked about in the oral arguments and in our comments in the proposed decision, that retroactive ratemaking and you have a legal lead recourse. And there's a potential, as Ted said in his script of an IRS issue, which is a normalization violation. So there's 2 different paths here that you might pursue. Hopefully, the commission addresses that as part of the final decision, but we will have to see. So if it were adopted and I think it was clearly in my prepared remarks. You had to take the $344 million [ph] off the rate base numbers for '15 through '17 to get back to unadjusted rate base approach.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I guess I would try to respond to it this way. If you pull up from looking at one year versus the next year, any individual year, which is kind of the larger theme, the larger trends, as you know, we try to strike this theme consis
componenttext: That's a good question. I guess I would try to respond to it this way. If you pull up from looking at one year versus the next year, any individual year, which is kind of the larger theme, the larger trends, as you know, we try to strike this theme consistently. We expect somewhere in this $4 billion plus kind of annual CapEx. We expect pretty significant rate base growth. And we expect that as the base gets larger, as the rate base gets larger, we're going to have more cash flow. So we feel that we could keep a good balance between solid annual CapEx and related earnings from a growing rate, base but cash to move us back in that 45% to 55%. Any given year, any couple of years, you might run a little hotter on CapEx. You might run a little slower on CapEx, that may give you a little -- on the margin, a little more room to move on dividends or slow it down a little bit. But fundamentally, I think rather than try to pick it apart year by year. That's the Teeter totter. It's keeping CapEx in that kind of $4-plus billion range and getting back solidly. I think I used the term well within the range of 45% to 55%. So I wouldn't get too ribbed up on any one year movement. Both of those things are going to be really what we're focused on. And we believe, as a result, we'll be able to provide investors with a higher than industry average growth rate in earnings and a higher than industry average growth rate in dividends.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll be happy to have a further discussion, but there's a lot of moving parts associated with AFUDC. Historically, the way we've done this over the last several years, we assume that AFUDC earnings offsets all the costs that are not recovered through the
componenttext: I'll be happy to have a further discussion, but there's a lot of moving parts associated with AFUDC. Historically, the way we've done this over the last several years, we assume that AFUDC earnings offsets all the costs that are not recovered through the ratemaking process. So those are -- there's executive compensation, board-related costs, our corporate dues and philanthropy activities. There's a whole bucket of that cost that aren't recovered. And we've assumed historically that AFUDC earnings offset those. And what can cause it to go up or down is the balance of what's in the account for the rate. So the rate can go up or down depending upon what's happening at any point in time. So I think for planning purposes, it's probably appropriate to assume that AFUDC will not come out again in the future in terms of providing a benefit and go back to that rate base approach as the core utility source of earnings and a little bit of energy efficiency that we've talked about repeatedly adjusted for the holding company cost to get you to a decent starting point.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Third Quarter 2015 Financial Teleconference. My name is Brandon. I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Third Quarter 2015 Financial Teleconference. My name is Brandon. I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Scott Cunningham, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Cunningham, you may begin your conference.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brandon, and welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team. Material
componenttext:
Thanks, Brandon, and welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team. 
Materials supporting today's call are available at www.edisoninvestor.com. The key items are our Form 10-Q, Ted and Jim's prepared remarks and the presentation that accompanies Ted's comments -- Jim's comments. Tomorrow afternoon, we will distribute our regular business update presentation. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about the future outlook for Edison International and its subsidiaries. Actual results could differ materially from current expectations. Important factors that could cause different results are set forth in our SEC filings. Please read these carefully. 
The presentation includes certain outlook assumptions as well as reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to the nearest GAAP measure. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to Ted.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported core earnings of $1.16 per share. While this is well below last year's third quarter core earnings of $1.52 per share, year-over-year third quarter earnings comparisons, as was the case wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported core earnings of $1.16 per share. While this is well below last year's third quarter core earnings of $1.52 per share, year-over-year third quarter earnings comparisons, as was the case with the first 2 quarters of the year, are not very useful. This is because of the way we have had to recognize revenue with the delay in SCE's 2015 General Rate Case and how we are accounting for the recently released proposed decision.
We have said in the past that we would provide 2015 earnings guidance when we received a final GRC decision. However, with the noise in our quarterly earnings numbers, we thought it a disservice to investors to have them guessing about 2015 earnings. Therefore, we decided it was best to provide 2015 guidance at this time today. 
So today, we introduced core earnings guidance for 2015 of $3.77 to $3.87 per share. This guidance has some key assumptions that Jim will review in his comments. Of course, should the final GRC decision differ substantially from the proposed decision, we may have to revisit our guidance. We plan to return to our normal practice of providing annual earnings guidance for 2016 when we report full year 2015 results in late February.
One more comment on the General Rate Case. While we feel the GRC proposed decision is overall generally constructive, SCE identified several important issues in its October 8 comments to the CPUC. Jim will cover most of these, but I want to touch on one in particular. 
The proposed decision attempts to recover certain tax repair benefits that were reflected in earnings in 2012 to 2014 through a permanent reduction to rate base of $344 million. We consider this retroactive ratemaking and a potential violation of internal revenue service rules. We are hopeful that the CPUC will correct their legal error. If the commission were to adopt the proposed decision's retroactive treatment of repair deductions, then SCE would be forced to write off some or all of the $380 million regulatory asset related to future recovery of taxes. The final decision on SCE's General Rate Case is currently scheduled for the November 5 CPUC meeting. 
I assume most, if not all of you, are aware of the administrative law judge's proposed decision released yesterday on penalties related to SONGS ex parte communications. In short, the ALJ found in her P.D. that there were 8 communications that were late reported to the commission and found 2 Rule 1.1 violations. The P.D. proposed a $16.74 million penalty on Southern California Edison. There are additional procedural steps yet to come on this issue, but we are thankful that this appears to be moving towards resolution.
This has been a painful episode, including for Edison, and I feel obliged to make several comments on it. First, I want to set the record straight on some misconceptions that are constantly being repeated. Contrary to the many reports, SCE has not engaged "improper talks or communications with regulators" related to the SONGS OII. The important distinction is that the judge found that we didn't report in a timely manner permissible communications with regulators. The communications themselves were not found to be improper or illegal under the ex parte roles, as certain parties have repeatedly and wrongly asserted.
In our recent filing, we maintained that 7 of these 8 communications were either not required or outright not allowed to be reported under the ex parte roles. The difference of opinion is a direct result of ambiguity in California's overly complicated ex parte roles. Ambiguous rules require the parties to do their best to interpret them and practice, which creates a risk. We believe the rules need to be clarified and simplified so that we do not find ourselves underwriting the risk of after-the-fact reviews. It is worth noting that even the ALJ concluded in her P.D. that the ex parte rules were ambiguous and cited that as a mitigating factor in calculating the penalty. As I said in an earnings call a few quarters ago, we look forward to working with President Picker to clarify the ex parte rules soon. 
Many of the matters we deal with in our business involve tough judgments -- tough judgment calls in contentious proceedings under ambiguous rules and conditions. We don't particularly like it, but it comes with the territory. We expect controversy. We also expect a great deal of ourselves and our employees because we provide such an essential service to society, and we rely on the public trust. That is why it is important to do the right thing. We expect nothing less of ourselves. We want to earn the trust of our customers, the public and the CPUC based on our conduct. While we aren't perfect and there will be times when we fail to live up to our own expectations and those of others, we must, and we do, set high standards of conduct for ourselves. We have an obligation to be transparent and open, and we will redouble our efforts to conduct ourselves in this manner. We will also work hard to support President Picker's efforts to clarify and improve the current poorly-crafted ex parte rules. Strong efforts on both fronts will go a long way to avoiding a repeat of this in the future.
On a brighter note, we were pleased to report last week the settlement reached with Nuclear Electric Insurance Limited, known as NEIL, on insurance claims related to the shutdown of the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station. The settlement is for $400 million and covers all insurance claims by the 3 owners of SONGS related to the events leading to the shutdown. All necessary approvals have been received from the owners and NEIL.
This is another important step in implementing the SONGS settlement approved unanimously by the CPUC last November. Consistent with the SONGS settlement, insurance recoveries will first pay associated legal costs, and then 95% will be allocated to customers and 5% to the owners. SCE customers will receive its allocation as a credit to the purchase power balancing account known as ERRA. Assuming payment from NEIL is received in the fourth quarter, then customer benefits should show up in their bills as a reduction in purchase power cost in 2016.
The larger claim against Mitsubishi Heavy Industries for the failed design of the replacement steam generators continues to proceed under binding arbitration through the International Chamber of Commerce. We still expect a decision on that case by late 2016.
SCE's share of the NEIL recoveries and any MHI recoveries, including recovery of legal costs, will be treated as noncore. That is, they will not be included in our core earnings.
There's still much procedurally to be accomplished before the SONGS OII and related matters can be completed. We are hopeful that this is all moving towards a conclusion this year or early next. We continue to believe that no new information has been presented to suggest that the SONGS settlement was anything other than independently negotiated that warrants full -- warrants continued full support by the CPUC and customers.
I'd like to turn to a couple of items that address some of our longer-term growth opportunities, starting with SCE's distribution resources plan, or DRP. Since the July 1 filing, we have seen tremendous interest among stakeholders and some encouraging early support from a number of parties on our conceptual long-term approach. Appropriately, there will be concerns about cost and the pace of implementation of building a flexible 21st century grid, as outlined in our DRP filing. We are awaiting a more definitive schedule for the balance of the preceding, which the CPUC indicates will be completed next spring. This should give SCE adequate time to incorporate DRP elements into its 2018 to 2020 General Rate Case, which we expect to file in the fall of 2016. 
Moving on, the California Legislature provided its own form of support for Governor Brown's low carbon goals and the DRP with the passage of Senate Bill 350. The governor signed this bill into law earlier this month. Senate Bill 350 will move renewables targets to 50% of delivered energy from qualifying renewable resources by 2030. The current renewables target is 33% of delivered power by 2020. The new law provides some valuable implementation flexibility that will help us meet the goals at the lowest reasonable cost to our customers. It also provided legislative support for future utility investment and transportation electrification. This was one of the long-term growth opportunities that we see for Southern California Edison, just as we see similar opportunities around electrical -- electric vehicle charging infrastructure and energy storage as complements to SCE's wire-focused investment strategy.
One final comment. I continue to believe that we have an attractive multiyear dividend opportunity that complements a strong earnings growth outlook. The GRC-proposed decision, the DRP and SB 350 are all data points that underscore SCE's growth potential. This, in turn, reaffirms the dividend growth opportunity I've discussed on recent earnings calls. We recognize that, for a few years now, we have been below our targeted payout ratio of 45% to 55% of SCE's earnings. We remain committed to moving well into that target range in steps over time.
Hopefully, we will be well along the way to resolution on both the SONGS OII and the GRC before the board's usual December consideration of the dividend increase. Even if both are not fully resolved by then, I don't see it impacting our ability to continue to implement our dividend policy. 
That concludes my comments. Now Jim will provide his financial report.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ted. Good afternoon, everyone. I plan on covering third quarter and year-to-date results, SCE's 2015 General Rate Case proposed decision, capital spending and rate base forecasts, a few other financial topics and guidance. Please turn to Page 2
componenttext:
Thanks, Ted. Good afternoon, everyone. I plan on covering third quarter and year-to-date results, SCE's 2015 General Rate Case proposed decision, capital spending and rate base forecasts, a few other financial topics and guidance. 
Please turn to Page 2 of the presentation. Let me first address revenue recognition for the first 6 months and then for the third quarter. For the first 2 months of the year -- excuse me, the first 2 quarters of the year, we recorded revenues largely based on 2014 authorized revenues, which included a revenue deferral of $85 million or $0.16 per share related to incremental flow-through tax repair deductions. Our accounting was based on management judgment that these revenues would likely be refunded to customers. Having received the proposed decision, we updated our estimate of probable refunds to customers as part of our third quarter reporting. This, in turn, lowered third quarter revenues. 
The GRC-related revenue reduction was $0.42 per share. This is comprised of the 2 elements shown under key earnings drivers at the right of the slide.
As Ted noted, earnings comparisons will not be useful until we receive a final GRC decision and report full year 2015 earnings. Of course, if the final GRC decision is different than the proposed decision, then there could be other related adjustments. 
With that background, I'd like to walk through the key earnings drivers, starting with SCE. There are 2 key earnings drivers of the $0.35 per share decline in SCE's earnings. First, as I mentioned before, we recorded revenue largely based on the GRC-proposed decision, including a catch-up adjustment; second, there were favorable cost and tax benefits realized in 2014, which did not recur in 2015.
Looking at revenue, I've highlighted the $0.42 per share related to the GRC-proposed decision. $0.20 of this revenue reduction is from the flow-through tax repair benefits to customers with a related offset in the form of higher tax repair deductions. The remaining decrease in GRC revenues are $0.22 per share. Also, we continue to see revenue increases from a growing FERC rate base and higher operating costs. This is a positive $0.02 per share.
Lastly, please note that the revenue variances is a net of SONGS for comparability. The SONGS detail are footnoted below. 
Moving to O&M. SCE had $0.03 per share in higher cost this quarter versus the third quarter of last year. This includes $0.01 per share of additional severance at SCE. Depreciation is $0.02 per share higher, primarily due to transmission and distribution investments. Net financing cost provided a $0.02 per share benefit, primarily due to higher earnings from AFUDC.
Turning to taxes. I've already covered the $0.20 per share for the 2015 repair deductions. Most of the remaining variance relates to $0.11 per share in earnings from incremental repair deductions recorded last year. In all, SCE's third quarter core earnings are $1.19 per share, down $0.35 from last year.
For the holding company, costs are $0.01 per share higher than last year, largely on lower income from Edison Capital. I'll come back to Edison Capital later in my remarks. 
Noncore earnings in the quarter of $0.13 per share largely relate to EME bankruptcy, tax benefits and insurance recoveries.
Please turn to Page 3. We've added this slide to simplify the explanation of third quarter core earnings. As you can see, the differences -- the difference on this slide versus the prior slide is that we netted out the impact of lower revenues and income tax benefits related to repair deductions in 2015. As indicated on this slide, the 2 key drivers are the lower revenues based on the GRC-proposed decision of $0.22 and the $0.11 of 2014 incremental repair deductions. That gets us to $0.33 of the $0.35 reduction in third quarter SCE core earnings. 
Please turn to Page 4. For year-to-date earnings, GRC-related revenue is $0.58 per share lower, reflecting the $0.42 for the third quarter and the $0.16 for the first half of the year. Again, this is a mix of lower tax repair revenues, $0.30 -- $0.36 per share, which is offset in taxes; and the third quarter revenue adjustment of $0.22 per share.
Most of the cost items continue their trend. And for the year-to-date, we also have higher depreciation and O&M and lower financing costs from higher AFUDC earnings. You will also see the significant impact in both years related to changes in uncertain tax positions and lower tax benefits in other areas. Last year, we also had the generator settlements and other items that are absent this year. All in, year-to-date SCE core earnings are $3.31 per share, down $0.27 from last year.
Page 5 has a similar waterfall chart of year-to-date core earnings. 
Please turn to Page 6. This slide compares the key revenue and rate base differences between the 2015 GRC proposed decision and SCE's updated request. The revenue adjustments recorded in the third quarter largely reflect the 3 quarters worth of proposed decisions authorized annual revenue.
Please turn to Page 7. This slide summarizes the most important issues identified in SCE's comments on the proposed decision. Ted has already talked about the tax repair deduction issue. 
Next is the customer deposit issue. Since the 2003 GRC, the CPUC has treated customer deposits as a rate base offset. However, PG&E and San Diego Gas & Electric do not have this adjustment. The third item is a proposed reduction in the pole loading program. The proposed decision did not approve approximately $100 million of capital, which has a 2015 rate base impact of $73 million. Putting aside the rate base adjustment for repair deductions, the proposed decision would adopt 92% of our requested capital. This is higher than previous GRCs and of course, this percentage could change with the final decision. 
I will note 2 other key issues. The principal one is incentive compensation. The proposed decision recommended significant reductions in authorized revenues related to incentive compensation for the entire workforce, even though the jointly sponsored SCE and ORA compensation study concluded SCE's total compensation is, on average, 5% below the market. We are strong believers in pay-for-performance compensation philosophy, and incentive-based compensation for all employees, not just executives, is a fundamental element of that philosophy. This reduction is larger than experienced in prior cases. 
Lastly, there is a $10 million disallowance for a contract termination payment dating back to SCE's commercial rooftop solar initiative. We believe the termination payment is reasonable and benefited customers substantially. 
In accounting for the quarter, the revenue adjustment tracks the proposed decision except for 2 items: the tax item and the solar program contract cancellation disallowance. I'll pick this up later when I discuss rate base forecast and earnings guidance.
Please turn to Page 8. Pages 8 and 9 update forecasted capital expenditures and rate base for the GRC-proposed decision and known FERC-related capital expenditure changes. SCE's experiencing licensing and permitting delays with 2 -- with a few of its transmission projects, notably the West of Devers project. As a result, the timing of expenditures was moved out beyond 2017. Once SCE files its 2018 GRC application and we update our CapEx and rate base forecasts, these delayed expenditures will appear back in the forecast. The FERC adjustments are shown on the right side of the slide. A balance of the reduction is related to the GRC proposed decision, largely infrastructure replacement, inspection and maintenance and nonelectric facility capital projects.
Historically, we have shown what we call a request level of capital expenditures and rate base and a lower range level. As you can see on the chart, on Pages 8 and 9, we have replaced the word request with the word outlook. For CPUC capital, we now forecast that we will spend all authorized dollars for 2015 through 2017. For FERC capital, we have continued our practice of reducing outlook expenditures by 12% to arrive at the range level of expenditures. Once we file our 2018 General Rate Case, we will revert back to using both request and range monikers. 
As a reminder, the CPUC capital expenditures do not include any distribution resources planned expenditures. We have asked the commission to approve a memorandum account so we can track costs associated with the DRP spending. So if we were to spend all authorized CPUC amounts provided in the GRC-proposed decision, then we would need to have the DRP memorandum account in place in order to be allowed to see cost recovery in the next GRC.
Beyond 2017, we still believe the long-term capital spending will continue to run at least $4 billion annually, and spending could be higher depending upon CPUC approval and future rate cases.
Please turn to Page 9. Based on a revised capital spending forecast from the prior slide, we have updated our rate base forecasts. The updated rate base forecast yields compound annual growth rates of 8% from 2017 -- excuse me, '15 through 2017. The prior forecast was 7% to 9% annually. Consistent with our accounting for the proposed decision, we have not factored in the proposed $344 million reduction in rate base related to the disputed tax repair deduction issue in this forecast. If the final GRC decision adopts the rate base adjustment, then each of the year's rate base would decline by the adjustment amount.
Please turn to Page 10. As expected, the CPUC cost of capital mechanism did not trigger any change in allowed ROE for 2016. While the spot Moody's Baa Utility Index rate moved quite a bit, the moving average dampened the full year impact. Starting October 1, we began the new measurement period, starting with the moving average, where the spot rate ended at September 30 at 5.45%. We are currently scheduled to file our next cost of capital application in April 2016.
Please turn to Page 11. This page covers a handful of other financial topics. SCE's weighted average common equity component, for regulatory purposes, was 49.5% at September 30, increasing from 48.9% we reported in the second quarter. This excess equity gives us additional financial flexibility.
Next, you will recall that SCE's fuel and purchase power balancing account, or ERRA, had been deeply under-collected as recently as year-end 2014. With the previous rate increase, SONGS settlement refunds, lower natural gas costs, the balancing account has moved to an over-collective position of $112 million as of September 30. When SCE receives the NEIL settlement proceeds expected in the fourth quarter, they will be credited to ERRA.
Turning to the holding company. Last month, we renewed an EIX holding company shelf registration to provide us flexibility to access the capital markets as needed for liquidity and general corporate purposes. EIX commercial paper outstanding was $738 million as of September 30 compared to a total EIX credit facility of $1.18 billion. 
Also, earlier this month, we reached an agreement to sell our remaining affordable housing portfolio at Edison Capital. Terms of the transaction have not been disclosed, pending final due diligence and negotiations. In any case, the amounts are not material, and the transaction will be treated as noncore. For the past few years, Edison Capital's earnings have helped offset holding company costs. 
Please turn to Page 12. This page provides detail of our 2015 earnings guidance that Ted discussed. We have followed the same approach we have used the last several years. We start with SCE rate base earnings. We use the $23.1 billion weighted average rate base outlook, as shown on Page 10. Based on SCE's authorized capital structure and flat share count, that gets us to $3.56 per share of rate base earnings. We then identify $0.41 per share of SCE items that take earnings higher. The principal item is the $0.31 per share revision to uncertain tax provisions recorded in the second quarter. We have also discussed AFUDC being a net positive factor for the year rather than just offsetting costs not recovered by the General Rate Case revenues. 
We continue to estimate $0.05 of energy efficiency earnings in the fourth quarter, as previously disclosed. We have recorded severance cost of $0.03 year-to-date. The balance of all items is a positive $0.01 a share, including the ex parte proposed penalty. We have estimated full year holding company cost at $0.15, getting us to a midpoint of $3.82 per share.
To the right, we have included key guidance assumptions. We had excluded the shareholder portion of the NEIL settlement proceeds and related litigation costs. We consider these revenues noncore. Our guidance tracks our accounting for the GRC proposed decision, so it excludes the $344 million rate base adjustment for repair deductions and the solar termination payment disallowance. 
That concludes my comments. I will turn the call over to the operator to moderate the Q&A.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Stephen Byrd with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Stephen Byrd with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: I just want to follow up on a couple of things in terms of spending outlook. The memorandum account for the DRP spend that you'd like to affect, could you talk a little bit procedurally just about how we should think about the steps to get approval for the memorandum account?

componenttextpreview: Well, we've actually filed for it. It was part of the DRP application that's gone in. And procedurally, the commission then will have to act. And I look it over with the SCE folks, any time frame for that? Pedro, are you in?
componenttext: Well, we've actually filed for it. It was part of the DRP application that's gone in. And procedurally, the commission then will have to act. And I look it over with the SCE folks, any time frame for that? Pedro, are you in?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Pedro Pizarro. Not just about the memo account, but procedurally, on the DRP filing, there's public workshops that are scheduled for November 9 to 10. And there, the PUC is looking at a broad DRP road map for hope that the DRP proceeding will
componenttext: Yes. This is Pedro Pizarro. Not just about the memo account, but procedurally, on the DRP filing, there's public workshops that are scheduled for November 9 to 10. And there, the PUC is looking at a broad DRP road map for hope that the DRP proceeding will be phased out in the next 3 to 4 years. With respect to the memo account itself, I don't think we have a specific timing. We expect it will be handled as the proceeding moves along next year.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then just a follow-up on -- just thinking about the tax positions you highlighted in 2015. There are a number of moving parts in terms of uncertain tax positions and lower tax benefits. On a going-forward basis in '16 and beyond, wit
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then just a follow-up on -- just thinking about the tax positions you highlighted in 2015. There are a number of moving parts in terms of uncertain tax positions and lower tax benefits. On a going-forward basis in '16 and beyond, without being specific numerically, how should we think about those kinds of moving parts? When do they start to settle down? And when will they become less material as we think about the future years?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, and it really depends on, ultimately, how things turn out. I can tell you, for repair deductions, that's been a challenging one for us to forecast accurately. And I wouldn't expect that, going forward, that you will see potential s
componenttext: That's a good question, and it really depends on, ultimately, how things turn out. I can tell you, for repair deductions, that's been a challenging one for us to forecast accurately. And I wouldn't expect that, going forward, that you will see potential shareholder benefits from repairs. But there could -- there are other tax benefits we realized, so it really becomes to how accurate we are forecasting our cost versus what actually occurs. So there could be differences, both for or against us. And the other related piece is O&M benefits. That's the other companion we've been talking about this whole time, where I think in the proposed decision, it was clear that it left open the door that there could be incremental O&M savings that we could realize. And we've said repeatedly that we will continue to look for benefits to reduce our cost for our customers.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then as you think about those moving parts, is that in terms of the magnitude of volatility? I know it's hard to have a crystal ball to think about that. But do you see the same degree of potential volatility in terms of movements in
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then as you think about those moving parts, is that in terms of the magnitude of volatility? I know it's hard to have a crystal ball to think about that. But do you see the same degree of potential volatility in terms of movements in these accounts? Or are there reasons why that volatility might be reduced in future years?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think my answer around that was because -- around repair deductions, where I was talking about specifically, the proposed decision, I think, effectively, will probably capture those benefits. And there's also a balancing account that has been set u
componenttext: Yes. I think my answer around that was because -- around repair deductions, where I was talking about specifically, the proposed decision, I think, effectively, will probably capture those benefits. And there's also a balancing account that has been set up for our pole loading program, which a lot of the repair deductions are arising from. That's why these repair benefits have increased so dramatically over the last 3 years. So with that balancing account, there's not an opportunity for earnings or losses associated with differences from forecast. A lot of complexity there. Sorry for all the -- there's still more to be written here until we get a final decision.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Weinstein with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Weinstein with UBS.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Julien here. So just following up here on the transmission reductions in the rate base. Can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of the issues in pushing up this CapEx, part one? And perhaps part two there, you talked about a $4 billion number. B
componenttext: It's Julien here. So just following up here on the transmission reductions in the rate base. Can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of the issues in pushing up this CapEx, part one? And perhaps part two there, you talked about a $4 billion number. But is that fair to say that there might be some higher oscillations in that, call it, rounded $4 billion number in the '18 period now that you've pushed out this transmission CapEx? Just trying to get a sense of exactly what's going on in terms of the moving pieces.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'll just point you to Page 8 in the investor deck, which has the capital expenditures, and it provides the detail of the amounts that are changing. In terms of the reasons, what my script followed up on was these are permitting and scheduling de
componenttext: Sure. So I'll just point you to Page 8 in the investor deck, which has the capital expenditures, and it provides the detail of the amounts that are changing. In terms of the reasons, what my script followed up on was these are permitting and scheduling delays. And the principal, the largest one, is the West of Devers project. There are some other smaller ones, but West of Devers is a rather large project, and we're just seeing it slip out in time. And I'll pause and look over at Pedro and Maria to see if there's anything else to add.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right.
componenttext: All right.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
